text:
Matt: Thanksgiving is nearly here...or it
happened like a month ago.
Sorry Canada.

But we’re not going to waste anyone’s
time debunking that tryptophan myth AGAIN

Judy: You’re not sleepy because of turkey
chemicals.

Sophia: It's just because you just ate too
much
Lauren: Guys, focus.

We at Speaking of Chemistry thought we’d
share some science we’re thankful for.
You won’t believe what Matt picked.
That guy.
Judy: Hi everybody.

I’m thankful for a little nutrient called
beta carotene, which can be found in Thanksgiving

favorites such as steamed carrots, sweet potatoes,
and pumpkin pie.

Besides adding that harvest orange color to
your family’s autumn feast, beta carotene

is a precursor to an important compound called
retinal, which is a form of vitamin A.

When light reaches the retinal in your eyes,
the molecule undergoes photoisomerization.

That means it absorbs energy from the light
and changes its orientations, going from kinked
to straight.

This change triggers a cascade of molecular
events that enables humans to see.

So scientists believe a healthy intake of
vitamin A and its precursor beta carotene
may prevent certain vision problems.

Now go and eat your veggies… especially
on Thanksgiving when they’re covered in
brown sugar and Cool Whip.
Yum!

Matt: I spend Thanksgiving in the Mitten State
with my family, watching the Detroit Lions
score all the football touchdowns. Go sports!
Sophia & Judy: Gooooo sports!

So I’m thankful for the jet fuel that helps
gets me home.

I’m also thankful for the scientists out
there making fuel more ecofriendly.
Right now, jet fuel comes from petroleum.

But, earlier this year, researchers derived
ketone molecules, like 2-pentanone and 2-heptanone,
from Brazilian sugar cane.

The team condensed these ketones and then
removed their oxygen atoms with the help of

inexpensive, recyclable catalysts to create
cyclic carbon molecules that could be used
as jet fuel.

Although these products are a ways from fueling
our planes, experts predict that making them would
produce much less greenhouse gas than refineries currently emit using petroleum-based methods.

Sophia: I’m thankful for friends and family
all over the world, and for the smartphone
that let’s me video chat with them.

Smartphones are made up of dozens of chemical
elements: nickel in the microphone, silicon

in the chip, and lithium in the battery, to
name a few.

But there are also rare earth elements that
make the screen colors vibrant--and let our
phones vibrate.

These elements aren’t called rare earths
because they’re rare per se.

It’s because they’re rarely found in big
enough deposits to mine effectively.

And we don’t have great replacements for
lanthanum, europium, dysprosium, all the other

good rare earth elements once we use ‘em
up.

The good news is researchers are improving
techniques to recover rare earth elements
from computers, cell phones, and other gadgets.
Thanks, science!

Lauren: This may not come as a shock since
I’m a chemist by training, but I’m thankful
for pharmaceuticals.

Specifically, I’m thankful for the drug
thyroxine, one of C&EN’s top pharmaceuticals
that have changed the world.

When I was little, I was diagnosed with something
called hypothyroidism.

That means that my thyroid gland doesn’t
make enough thyroxine--a hormone that regulates

all sorts of processes in the body, including
metabolism.

When my doctors figured this out, they prescribed
a synthetic version of thyroxine that I now
take in pill form.

It replaces my missing hormone and helps keep
me at a health weight and from being tired
all the time.

It also helps me stay focused so I can wrangle
these guys.
Sophia: How about that internet?
Matt: Oh my gosh!
Did you the video with the cat on the Roomba?

It was like rrrrrrrrrrrrrrr and like just
going around and stuff.

Lauren: And of course, we’re thankful for
you, our viewers.

To show our gratitude, we’re going to reward
one lucky commenter with some sweet Chemoji swag.

Share a piece of chemistry that you’re thankful
for in the comments section below.
We’ll choose our favorite…
Sophia: At random.
Lauren: ...to receive the prize.

While you’re at it, take a gander at this
video from our friends at ACS Reactions about
what does happen when you eat too much.
